= Alchemy Database's Documentation =

The documentation is a work in progress.

  * Alchemy Database can do a lot of things, check out [http://code.google.com/p/alchemydatabase/wiki/CommandReference CommandReference]
  * Alchemy Database is VERY fast, scales well when joining or when using multiple indexes, check out [http://code.google.com/p/alchemydatabase/wiki/Benchmarks Benchmarks]

  * Starting at release 0.2, AlchemyDB uses a REST API, described [http://code.google.com/p/alchemydatabase/wiki/RestAPI here]
  * Still Want to write a client, or extend an existing one, best to have a firm grasp of the [http://code.google.com/p/alchemydatabase/wiki/Protocol Alchemy Database Protocol]

  * Development branch code, fork at will via [https://github.com/JakSprats/Alchemy-Database Github] - *RECOMMENDATION:* use github
  * latest Release Candidate: [https://github.com/JakSprats/Alchemy-Database/tree/release_0.2_rc1 release_0.2_rc1]


  * Jaksprats (author) [http://jaksprats.wordpress.com/ blog] discussing the strengths and uses of Alchemy Database

  * An experimental [http://code.google.com/p/alchemydatabase/wiki/AppStack web_server] mode speaks HTTP and calls whitelisted Lua functions to server web pages

  * Document-Store & Object-Database functionality have been added to AlchemyDB via the [http://code.google.com/p/alchemydatabase/wiki/LuaTableColumnType LuaTable] column

  * A [http://code.google.com/p/alchemydatabase/wiki/LuaGraphDB Graph Database] built on AlchemyDB. SQL for indexing and Lua for graph-traversal logic.

  * A draft that lists Alchemy Databases highlights can be found [http://code.google.com/p/alchemydatabase/wiki/HighLights here]

=== DEPRECATED ===
